headline: When Power Seeks the Ballot
author: Publius

content:
The accumulation of all powers, legislative, executive, and judiciary, in the same hands, whether of one, a few, or many, and whether hereditary, self-appointed, or elective, may justly be pronounced the very definition of tyranny.

— James Madison, Federalist No. 47, February 1, 1788

The American Founders argued fiercely about many things. They disagreed about banks, standing armies, executive power, and the proper scope of the national government. But on one question, they were remarkably aligned: whoever controls elections controls the republic, and that power must never be centralized.

Recent calls to “nationalize” elections should therefore be understood not as policy debate, but as a warning flare. The Founders anticipated this moment. They built the Constitution to prevent it.

The Design Was Deliberate

The Constitution does not leave election administration to the states by accident or omission. It does so deliberately, as a structural safeguard against tyranny.

Article I, Section 4 grants states the authority to run elections, with Congress permitted to regulate the manner of federal elections only as a backstop, never as an administrator. The national government may protect access, prevent discrimination, and ensure that elections occur. It may not seize the machinery of voting itself.

To the Founders, this distinction was essential. The same authority that seeks power must never be allowed to choose the conditions by which it is granted.

Madison’s Warning: The Referee Cannot Be the Player

James Madison understood this danger more clearly than anyone. His central concern, expressed again and again, was the concentration of power:

The accumulation of all powers, legislative, executive, and judiciary, in the same hands, whether of one, a few, or many, and whether hereditary, self-appointed, or elective, may justly be pronounced the very definition of tyranny.

Elections were not peripheral to Madison’s thinking. They were the primary mechanism by which power was restrained.

A national government that controls elections would no longer be checked by them. It would be self-certifying. To Madison, that is not reform. It is collapse.

Hamilton’s Warning: The Demagogue’s Path

Alexander Hamilton was no apostle of weak government. He argued forcefully for a strong executive and a capable national state. Yet Hamilton understood that the gravest threat to liberty rarely announces itself as tyranny.

In the opening essay of The Federalist, Hamilton warned that “a dangerous ambition more often lurks behind the specious mask of zeal for the rights of the people than under the forbidden appearance of zeal for the firmness and efficiency of government.”

He had studied history. He knew the pattern. “Of those men who have overturned the liberties of republics,” Hamilton wrote, “the greatest number have begun their career by paying an obsequious court to the people; commencing demagogues, and ending tyrants.”

The warning is precise. Those who claim to act in the people’s name, who wrap their ambitions in the language of popular sovereignty, are the ones most likely to destroy what they claim to protect.

Jefferson’s Blunt Truth: Liberty Erodes Quietly

Thomas Jefferson put the matter plainly:

The natural progress of things is for liberty to yield, and government to gain ground.

Jefferson believed local control, especially over elections, was liberty’s shield. Centralizing elections would strike him not as efficiency, but as distrust: distrust of citizens, distrust of local communities, distrust of self-government itself.

A government that claims it must control elections to preserve legitimacy is, in Jefferson’s view, already illegitimate.

The Founders’ Deeper Fear

The Founders were not naïve. They had studied Rome, England, and the republics of Europe. They knew the pattern:

First, leaders claim elections are corrupt. Then they centralize control “temporarily.” Rules tighten. Opposition becomes suspect. Elections continue, but choice disappears.

They designed the American system to prevent that sequence. Claims of fraud were not, to them, a justification for seizing elections. They were the very reason elections had to remain outside centralized power.

A government that truly trusts its people does not fear decentralization. A government that fears decentralization is confessing something else.

What the Founders Would Ask

The Founders would not begin with slogans or legal technicalities. They would ask a simpler question:

Who benefits from controlling the vote?

And their answer would be immediate:

Not the people. Not liberty. Not the republic.

They would recognize “nationalizing elections” for what it is: the logic of rulers who no longer trust the governed, justified by fear and dressed in the language of order.

They had a name for this trajectory. Madison called it tyranny. Hamilton warned it would entrench power. Jefferson saw it as liberty’s slow death.

The Warning They Left Us

The American experiment rests on a fragile premise: that those who govern must submit themselves to rules they do not control. Once that principle is abandoned, no parchment barrier can save the republic.

The Founders did not believe law alone could preserve liberty. But they knew this much: a government that controls elections has already crossed the line from servant to master.

The question is no longer what they would say.

It is whether we are still listening.

Hold Fast
